Subject: Lori Stish - Hazleton Area School District - Mr. Jeffrey Weed- LEA
Body: It is important to engage families in the development of measurable annual goals because the family may want a particular skill for their child to be successful with. Sending home, a parental survey before the annual IEP is helpful in determining what goals to develop. It is important to start with a baseline and then you get to see the progress the students are making. It also helps you to decide that if along the way you may need to modify and/or adjust the goal by adding an intervention. IEP meeting are very intense but encouraging and having the parents participate in goal develop can ease the process.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Shauna Tretinik - Gifted/Enrichment at Central Greene School District, Edith Woods - CGSD Director of Special Education
Body: I feel that it is very important to engage the students and their families in the development of annual goals.  Many of my parents want their students to continue to be challenged in their learning.  Setting independent research goals, goals for leadership and time management help my students prepare for college and their career paths.  Discussions with their families while planning these goals help my students to understand why they are important.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Casey Cappello - West Shore SD
Body: Having students know what their goals are from an early age helps engage them in their goals. Student engagement and active communication with the student and family will help in the creation of measurable goals in the IEP.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: James Flick - AHCCS/Trina Knauff
Body:
A good strategy to start with is to review the student’s baseline date and progress for academic, function, and transitions needs, with the student, parents/guardians, and IEP team. This helps all members of the team understand how the student is achieving currently for in academic and functional need areas. The review should also the student’s progress from the previous year to inform the determination of goal criteria for the current IEP.


Another strategy is to maintain an open line of communication. Parent/Guardians and the student can be engaged by sending home input forms to gather input on the strengths and weaknesses of the student.


Leaving time during the meeting for the family and/or student to give their feedback and concerns is another strategy I have seen work routinely. This helps foster agreement and make sure there is consensus on the IEP for the student.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Terri Mitchell- South Allegheny School District (Nicole Homistek)
Body: To engage youth and family in the development of measurable annual goals, open communication is the key.  Gaining information from family, student, and teachers can help to identify areas of need and create goals.  Progress monitoring on the goals every grading period keeps the family and student up to date on progress.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Brianna Littzi - Wyoming Area School District (LEA - Vanessa Nee)
Body: Engaging families and youth with the development of measurable annual goals is essential to transition. The best way to do this is to involve families and youth in each step along the way. Having continuous communication with students and families is so important throughout the entire process. Giving everyone involved an opportunity to provide feedback and discuss changes and needs is crucial. It is also important to be in touch with your student’s strengths, needs, personal goals, and interests to aid in the development of measurable annual goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sarah Loughnane - Abington Heights School District (LEA: Elizabeth Shivock & Thomas Evans)
Body: Engaging families requires keeping the lines of communication open and communication ongoing with all participants in the IEP team. Data collection should be conducted regrading a student's areas of strength, growth, and post-secondary goals through the utilization of student surveys, transition surveys, self assessments, parents surveys, and teacher input. Fostering an environment where students and families feel they have a say is imperative and teaches self advocacy skills that better aid in the development of goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Michele Fischer - FCASD
Body: I believe that in order to develop a strong measurable annual goal, you need to work as a team. Together through communication with student, parent, general ed teacher(s) and special ed teacher and using data gleaned from formal and informal assessments the team will be able to develop measurable annual goals necessary to ensure the student's post-secondary success.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Marisa Cleer - Bradford Area School District (Jennifer Morgan - LEA)
Body: One way to get students and families more engaged in the development of MAGs is by continually updating and reviewing student progress through data collection and progress monitoring. A report should then be compiled and sent home multiple times per year to share collected data with the family. At any time, the IEP team can review the collected data and develop goals off that data and create/revise goals based off need.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: MAGS
Body:
Donald Stitt  Jennifer Morgan (LEA)

To get students and families engaged in MAGs is to continue to review and update student's progress towards their goals through progress monitoring and data collection.  A report should be sent home at the end of each marking period stating the progress on the goal through curriculum based assessments and progress monitoring data collection.  Other progress reports during the marking period to give reports on curriculum based assessments.  These reports should be used to revise and update the student's MAGs.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Angela Avillion-Hazleton Area School District
Body: The best way to engage families when developing annual goals is to involve them in every step of the process. The team must understand the students' strengths and weaknesses and look to the post-school goals to write measurable annual goals that will help the  student reach that post-school outcome. Always keeping the big picture in mind will insure that goals are both meaningful, and appropriate for the student.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Leslie Bloomgren - Warren County School District
Body: Open and honest communication regarding school progress, for both academic and functional levels of performance.  Data should be based on multiple measures and discussed as a team and distributed to families at least every quarter. Students should know what their goals are and whether or not they are making progress towards their goals. That should be discussed with students either weekly or bi-weekly.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Anonymous
Body: To engage the student and family in the development of measurable annual goals, it is important to talk about their expectations, their wants, and their stuggles so that your MAG is aligned with their expectations of accomplishment.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Andrea Kirchner, South Allegheny School District
Body:
I engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals by sending out Parent Input forms, interviewing the student, conducting
classroom observations, and providing students and families with progress monitoring data every nine weeks.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Amy North - North East School District - LEA Brianne Hodges
Body: To engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals open and honest communication needs to take place. This can happen through interviews or surveys. Measurable annual goals should begin by being based on data obtained from evaluation reports, then should grow from there with student needs. Data should be collected on goals and reviewed through progress monitoring to ensure that goals are being met or if they need to be modified.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Tricia Marnell-Hazleton Area School District...Jeff Weed-LEA
Body: Teachers... Know your students!!!! This is vital.  It's also important to include information from parents, teachers, and other stake holders to ensure that goals are realistic.  Using current and appropriate assessment data is key to efficient progress monitoring.  Continuous feedback to and from the team on a regular basis ensures all of the above "team players" are working together in the best interests of the student.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: C. Campbell
Body: Open lines of communication and knowing the student's capabilities are crucial. The development of goals should be based on information obtained from the parents, school staff, data and the student.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lorrie Logsdon- BASD  (Shane Bingman-LEA)
Body: When developing measurable goals for student's IEP, it takes more than just the IEP team. The goals must be data supported but should also include student input and parent/family involvement. Even teacher input from other teachers can be helpful. With the inclusion of parents/students and the IEP, the results for the student's success will be positive. Having conversations with students will also allow the IEP team to get to know the students and their own personal goals and interests .
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Marc Mayer- South Allegheny
Body: Knowing the student is very important.  Gaining info. from teachers, family, and the student will help to identify goals.  Using assessment data is key to monitoring progress.  Giving feedback to the team on a regular basis ensures all stakeholders are working together to hep the student reach the goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Shawna Dolata- South Allegheny
Body: The best way to engage in the development of measurable annual goals is by working with the team in the development of the goals. When in the IEP meetings I will discuss the goals and what I see fit for the student, based on the present Ed baseline data, to be working on this IEP year. The parents and the team are there and are able to make suggestions if they agree or disagree with the goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Module 7
Body:
It is important to engage youth and families in the development of IEP goals by discussing academic and functional needs with them and getting their input on what they feel would be most beneficial for the student. The goals should be based on multiple sources of input and address the areas that are identified as the highest level of need for the student.
Nicole Latini - South Allegheny
Author: Anonymous

Subject: CStudt: FCASD/Mahoney
Body: The most important thing when engaging students and families in developing measurable annual goals is communication. All team members need to be involved when creating measurable annual goals. Communication should occur throughout the school year to make sure everyone is on the same page when it comes to what is working and not working for student.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Module 7
Body:
Communication between families, student, and teacher is important prior to developing goals.  Monitor and adjust the goals within IEP as needed to best meet the needs of the student.  Progress monitoring to collect data helps make an informed decision and discussion with team members.
Laura Miller- FCASD
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Selene Schagen--Hazleton Area School District; Jeff Weed--LEA
Body:
There are many ways to engage your students and their parents in the development of measurable annual goals.  I believe an open line of communication is key to this.  From the start of each school year, I try to establish an open line of communication with each of the students and their families.  Weekly emails as well as Google texts allow all parties to express any concerns at any time.  

In addition to allowing the communication to occur on an on-going basis, it gives everyone an opportunity to express what is working and not working in school.  Then, the paper-pencil assessments (survey's and input forms) also give the student and parent a chance to express feedback that relates to transition  and the current measurable goals, that can then be discussed further at the IEP meeting.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Module 7
Body:
Most secondary students and their families are not new to the IEP process.  It is important for them to be involved in all aspects in the planning and revisions of the current IEP.  Evaluation Reports provide valuable information about the educational history.  There should be a continuation of goals from previous IEPs that are updated, revised and modified unless there is data to support that the goal is met. Students should have a clear understanding of their strengths, needs and progress and are active participants in this process.

Jennifer Pro - FCASD - LEA - Tim Mahoney
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Roger Sullenberger-FCASD
Body: The development of measurable annual goals  should always be based on data obtained from the initial evaluation report and/or any reevaluation reports. This may also include information obtained from the parents, teachers and school staff working with the student and who have knowledge of the child's current strengths and needs. We ultimately engage parents in this process by inviting their input and gathering information from them. We also engage them in this process by ensuring they are participants at IEP meetings, staffings, and in conversations through regular communication with them via phone, email or online sources.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Ashley Roomsburg - Northeastern York School District
Body: I use various methods to engage youth and families in developing measurable annual goals. To engage the students, I like to work on surveys and questions within the classroom to find the students' interests. I like to work with them to think about transition goals they may not yet be thinking about. I also like to explore careers and different ideas with them to see what they would like to do and learn more. To engage the families, I like to send them home surveys as well to start thinking about different ideas of what they would like to see happen for their child both in the classroom and in the future. I like to use this as a starting point so we can discuss and collaborate during the IEP meeting in order to have the best possible goals for the student.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
To engage youth and families in goal writing, typically looking at the RR reports, assessments and data to find areas of need and communicate that information to the IEP team. Teacher observations are also very helpful especially with behavioral or executive functioning goals.  An IEP is initially a draft so all input is needed and a goal can be discussed, changed or modified.  Progress monitoring is helpful once a goal is put in place to ensure that the student is on the right path and the expectations are not to high or low for success.  
A. Deasy - FCASD - LEA - Tim Mahoney
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Anna Hopper- FCASD
Body: It's important to provide accurate information when it comes to student needs and how the student needs correlate to post secondary goals.  Providing this information to students and families is helpful when showing why these goals are appropriate.  Also, having open conversations with students and families, asking for their input, and providing that honest conversation is helpful.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Module 7
Body:
Communication between the student, family and school is essential before an IEP meeting.  Everyone should have input when developing goals.  The document is just a draft and should be discussed and adjusted for the benefit of the student.  Progress monitoring is important to ensure that goals are being met or if there is a need to modify them.
Jane Hudok- FCASD
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Barbara E. Susanj-Northeast Bradford School District; NEB Jr. Sr. High School (LEA)
Body:
Engaging youth requires lots of in person conversations with students. As well as parent/guardian surveys along with their input towards future goals and skills they would like to see developed beyond just academic skills.  Parent Conference nights or Google classroom provides parents the opportunity to regularly communicate with case managers just beyond the school email or phone conversations. 
All IEP meetings are supposed to be just drafts of the document therefore all additions or changes should be discussed and made with the entire team's input at that time of the meeting. 
Providing some positive behavior supports and rewards with students has worked with previous students as well.  Setting up individual goals and rewards with those goals gives students something to strive for over the marking periods.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Open communication with students and families during the development of MAGs is essential. When there is a positive relationship between the school and families, it allows for all members of the IEP team to be open and share ideas for MAGs. It is also important to know the student’s strengths, needs, and interests when writing MAGs.

-Britney Robinson, FCASD
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Candace Bush-Keystone Oaks School District
Body: Before the IEP team meeting a conversation can occurr with the parents and student to create the goals.  The conversation can start with the progress that was made and the weaknesses that need to be addressed.  Then talk about ways the weaknesses can be address and develop the goals together.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Amy Marcho, Elizabeth Shivock, Abington Heights School District
Body: To engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals It is important to review in detail what the progress means of each goal means and how that specific student compares to his/her same age general education peers.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Coffee Talk - Module 7
Body: When creating a goal for a student, provide all information that you considered when creating it to the student and family.  Be sure to be respectful of the student and clear in why this is a part of the IEP document.  Whenever possible, ask for input from the family on if they feel the goal is measuring the ultimate goals that the student has for future post-secondary life.  G Hetu/FCAHS
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Module 7
Body: Communication between students and parents is an integral part of the process.  Everyone should have a clear understanding of the goals, how they will be measured, and progress towards these goals.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Open communication is imperative if the teacher wants to engage the student and the family in the development of the goals.  Both frequent discussion with the teacher and transition surveys help determine needs.  Parents should also use transition forms and continue discussions with the educator.  At the time of the IEP more discussion should be had to ensure all needs are being considered.  After the IEP progress monitoring can help determine and ensure that the goals are being met.

Kevin Grecek FCASD
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Ryan Snyder-Interboro SD
Body:
Youth and families can be involved in the development of the measurable annual goals because the the youth should know their strengths and weaknesses.  The goals should be aligned with their transition grid as well.

Youth and families should know what the assessments that are given tell us about the student and then work as a team to build and align the rest of the IEP.  

Goals should be easily understood by all parties and able to be monitored for progress throughout the year.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Dianna Bain - Redbank Valley SD
Body: Having students and family be active members of the  IEP team  is key to keeping families engaged in the development of measurable annual goals.  Keeping the student and families updated to all current progress monitoring helps everyone on the team know exactly where the student is functioning.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Erica Shearer- West Shore School District
Body: Communicating with and engaging families during the development of MAGs is critical. Having open and frequent discussions with parents and students is important in building rapport and trust between the teacher and family. When there is a positive relationship between the school and families, it allows for all members of the IEP team to be open and share ideas for MAGs. It is also important to know the student’s strengths, needs, and interests when writing MAGs.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sue Middaugh- Northeast Bradford School District- Shannon Gorman, LEA
Body: To engage youth and families in the development of goals, you need to have open communication. Having youth complete transition questionnaires and discussions with their case managers will provided insight into what the student needs. Parents should complete a Parent Input form, a transition questionnaire and talk/email the youths case manager with their concerns and thoughts on their youths' needs. During the IEP meeting a continued discussion is required to make sure that the needs are going to be addressed. On going discussion after progress is provided will ensure that needs are being met.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Mary Harris, Northeast Bradford SD, Shannon Gorman, LEA
Body: Students should be progressed monitored regularly and this should be communicated to the parents regularly.  Communication is key to success for students.  When progress monitoring, it is important to let the students know why you are progress monitoring.  Explain to them about their goals.  Let them know how they can achieve their goals.  Show them how they are doing, how close they are towards achieving their goal.  Ask the parents and the students if they feel there is something the student should have a goal for.  Discuss what the goal should be and what they need to do to acheive that goal.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Rachel Lambert
Body: Students need to know what their assessments are yielding. Sharing their results will also help write the goals. So the student knows why these assessments and monitoring are being administered. Goals should also be able to be monitored easily by the teacher.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Hanah Soucy-WSSD
Body: Engaging families in the development of measurable annual goals is important. Having frequent communication with the student and parents and involvement through the IEP planning process is critical. Having this relationship will help build trust and communication to provide for a positive min-set when writing an IEP and goals. Also, knowing your students strengths and needs will help build a conversation to address how we as a team can best address and meet those needs.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Timothy McCracken- Central Fulton School District
Body: The way I get students and families involved in the MAG writing process is by first communicating to student and family assessment results.   Next having discussions with both parents and the student as to what areas of concern they feel need the most help or improvement.  Then together as a team we can decide based on interest, plans for the future, etc,  areas that need the most help/ attention and come up with a goal to help improve this area.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Andrea Walker: West Shore SD
Body: Students should be involved in developing their MAGs. Parents and families should also be involved in this process through communications, such as phone calls and attendance at meetings. Parents and students should be given information from data collection sources, such as progress monitoring, observations, assessments, interviews, etc. The IEP team can discuss with families the student's strengths and needs.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sarah Bolton- Wyoming Area School District (LEA- Vanessa Nee)
Body: We can engage youth and families in the development of Measurable Annual Goals by working to collaborate as a team. Providing families opportunities to share input on the students' behaviors, strengths, and weaknesses, and insight into the IEP process, allow for families concerns and ideals to be valued. Encouraging ongoing  communication between all team members,  and consistently monitoring, and sharing students' progress, helps maintain family and student engagement.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Michael Ketterman-WSSD
Body: In order to engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals, they need to be educated on the transition purpose by demonstrating the What? Why? and How? of the process. Another important factor is to keep open communication with clear and concise information about the plan. Age-appropriate assessments will allow for a more accurate model in developing measurable annual goals. If we allow students choice and to express the importance of it's ok to not know, this will give students the confidence and knowledge to be able to change their minds about what they might want to pursue.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Melissa Finch-Northeast Bradford HS- Shannon Gorman/LEA
Body: It is important to engage both the student and their families in the development of measurable annual goals. To engage students and families, providing frequent opportunities for communication regarding strengths, interests, needs, and other critical information will aid in the development of annual goals to prepare and guide students for success in those areas. Families may be able to provide important information that teachers/staff may miss.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Dayton Tweedy, Central Fulton School District

In order to get student involvement in the development of measurable goals, I go over assessment results with the student. After identifying areas of strength, we talk about possible areas for improvement. For example, if the student did not score well in fractions, long division, and solving algebraic equations, we talk about which is most important to the student's interest in becoming a welder. Since fractions are essential in reading a tape measure, we decide on fractions as an area for an annual goal. For parent involvement, I use parent surveys and interviews (often by phone) to see what is most important to the parents.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Mikaela Quintois- west Shore School District ExCEL
Body: To engage students and families in the participation on developing goals, it is important to keep open communication before starting the process. Allowing and encouraging families to be engaged throughout the whole planning process ensures that each member is involved. Another important part is talking to students about their goals and the importance of setting these goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Heather Strait, CFSD, McConnellsburg- LEA: Holly Varner
Body: In order to ensure student and family participation in MAG, it is important to first teach students about setting goals and the importance of goal setting. Have student/guardians fill out surveys to provide feedback and express post-secondary goals. Have student and family identify his/her strengths and needs to meet postsecondary goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kayla Ziegler (LEA); Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body: I think engaging youth and families in the development of their goals begins with open communication. It's essential that they are key participants in the meetings to be able to determine data for the student's academic, functional, and transition needs. It is also helpful to review previous years data with the IEP team in order to determine what their goal criteria might look like for their current IEP. Ultimately, feedback (whether positive or negative) from the student and family is vital so we, as an IEP team, can support and assign goals that are appropriate.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Emily Frederick-Bradford Area School District (BASD)
Body:
There are a few ways you could engage families and you in the development of measurable annual goals. First, communication and involvement within the whole IEP planning process is important. When families and students feel involved better input and discussion occur. Positive relationships amongst all team members is also important to meet a common goal. The measurable annual goals must be student centered. They should also be attainable and work as stepping stones towards the end goal for the given student. Lastly, sharing progress on the goals with the families will help keep them updated on progress and provide them with a chance to voice concerns if the child is not making progress or if any stakeholder feels a new area needs explored. 


Emily Frederick-Bradford Area School District (BASD)
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jennifer Barnes-BASD
Body: To help develop MAG having good communication with parents and students is important. Have the parent and student participate from the beginning of the IEP process- from invites, assessments (which are use to drive the IEP process and help monitor growth), and development of transition section. Have communication and trust with the parents and students. This will allow for a positive mind-set for writing an IEP and creating MAGs.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Mike Lewis - Quaker Valley SD
Body: Here at QV we work to create, keep and maintain lines of communication with all stakeholders when it comes to developing measurable goals.  We start by gathering the input of the students and families that we are working with and develop goals from there.  That line of communication remains open so that when a student meets a goal or finds that they are struggling to meet a goal, communication is established and can be ongoing.  Making sure that considerations to change a goal are shared with all is key.  All stakeholders in a student's IEP need to have the opportunity to share insight that supports making a change during the year and leading up to the yearly IEP meeting.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
To make sure that everyone is engaged in the development of measurable annual goals, it is important to make sure that everyone is aware of the student's strengths and needs. Communication with all parties is necessary to discuss what needs are being addressed and how to best address them. Discussing strengths and needs with the student, teachers, and parents will help to make sure that everyone is involved in the process.

Beth Baranowski, City Charter High School (Josh Hanna)
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Daniel K. Mills - Interboro School District- LEA Rachel Lambert
Body: It is paramount that all stakeholders have an open line of communication.  Staff will need to meet with students and parents to have conversations and utilize assessments to drive the IEP process and monitor growth towards the students goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lorie Pezzano - Shenango Area School District (James Janacone LEA)
Body: I feel that communication among the regular education teacher, special education teacher, parents and student is the key to student success.  Including students & parents in the IEP process from step one of the IEP Invitation, to the formal and informal (parent & student surveys) assessments and throughout the IEP meeting & discussion of student post secondary goals and annual academic goals. This cooperation and communication will help align and enhance student success. I use a daily communication sheet/google form (between reg ed teachers, special ed teacher and parent) which reports a "quick glance" of student performance throughout his/her classes each day.  Parents appreciate the communication.  This form is also used as a progress monitoring tool for student behavior.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Timothy Hanson- Interboro SD (Rachel Lambert-LEA)
Body: Students should be be formally assessed on a  yearly basis in order to assess progress to make changes to their Goals as students progress. Students should be aware of their MAG and over the course of the year how they are progressing on them. Students that are invested are more likely to put the work in to improve. Continued communication with the family is important so they are aware of progress and can offer input into other information that may influence progress.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Alicia Brough, Interboro School District, LEA- Rachel Lambert
Body: Ongoing communication should occur between the families, youth, and members of the IEP team.  Parents should be informed of the student's goals, the progress they are making, and the supports in place to help the student meet the goals. There should also be open commuincation about the student's future goals (after graduation) to make sure that everything is aligned and the student is getting the services needed
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Pam McCloskey, Interboro School District
Body: To engage students and families in the development of MAGS, open and ongoing communication is essential. The student's strengths and needs must be discussed as well as the student's and families' plans for post-graduation.  It is important to update the goals, plans, strengths and needs annually to ensure a successful transition to post-secondary living.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Shannon Oden - Interboro SD (Rachel Lambert - LEA)
Body: It is vital that all team members play a role in the development of a student's MAGs. Students and their families can provide valuable information and feedback that can be used in the development of their MAGs. Students are also administered formal assessments that will provide data that shows certain areas of weakness. It is also important that students are aware of their annual goals and how they are monitored. Students should be a part of the discussion about what areas of needs are being focused on and why.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Stacey Thierry - Boyertown Area School District (LEA - Kalyn Bartman)
Body: Students and families are part of the IEP team and have a large part in the development of the IEP itself. Utilizing student and parent input, frequent communication, sharing of data gathered, etc. is discussed prior to and at the IEP meeting with student and parents to discuss and develop MAGs. The MAGs are developed based off of the student's transitional goals which are determined by student's dreams/goals after graduation. Having every IEP team members' input in the goals is imperative in order to ensure goals are appropriate and obtainable.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Ed Petch, Hazleton Area School District, LEA- Jeff Weed
Body: Meeting with students, parents, and staff will need to meet and have open honest communication. This communication should not just occur during or immediately prior to the IEP meeting. Communication with families should be on going throughout the year. In these conversations, assessments and the results should be discussed. These discussions will allow parents and students to understand what student choices are, supports needed to reach those goals, and the supporting data. This data includes parent input and student self-reflection.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Stephanie Davis Russell Byers Charter School LEA Tracey Lank
Body: Families  begin the transition process with their child in middle school. Before the IEP meeting and throughout the student and family members have input and an understanding of the child's goals. Families contribute input forms before the IEP meeting. The strengths and needs of the student reflect in the student's measurable annual goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Danielle Bereschak, Environmental Charter School, LEA: Ali Rendulic
Body: When engaging students and their families in the development of measurable annual goals it is important to make sure they are actively engaged in the progress of their goals and understanding them. When it comes time for an annual IEP make sure you send home parent input form and interview the student at school. Take this information, and your assessment information along with progress monitoring data, and combine it to form meaningful goals. Take this information and share it with the family and with the student and ensure they understand it and feel ownership in it as well. If they don't, listen to them to see why and fix it.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kelly Sandrock - Hazleton Area School District (LEA Jeff Weed)
Body: In order to develop measurable goals, there needs to be communication among all the IEP team members along with accurate data of the students ability levels.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Dane Barhite Mountain View School District- LEA ERICA LOFTUS
Body: Caretakers and students can be given questioneers and input forms to complete. We can gather input from them before, during and after a meeting. Also, we can constantly inform students and families on progress the student is making towards their goals setting them up for success.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jena Albaugh - Warren County School District
Body: Students and parents need to be included in the development of measurable annual transition goals through open dialogue, interest inventories and surveys.  These need to be on-going and fluid so that if a student's interests change, the goal can be modified.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Rachel Faieta: Jefferson Morgan (Sara Bates)
Body: To engage youth and families in the development of annual goals, it is important to incorporate all important persons in the IEP process. These individuals together complete a “team” by completing parent surveys, student surveys, and open communication between all. Outside agencies (if applicable) would also be a part of this team as well. Having all these members together will help incorporate their input into determining the best development of the student’s measurable goals.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Gino Molino - Hazleton - LEA - Jeff Weed
Goals need to be realistic.

Subject: Brad Ward--PPS--Dr. Frioni

Subject: Alyssa Cipriano: Hazleton Area School District, Mr. Jeffrey Weed, LEA
Body:
Open communication with youth and families is very important. At the beginning of the year, I make sure to contact all of my families either by phone or email. I also send home a “Million Words or Less” paper which asks the parent to tell me about their child. This gives me insight into their strengths, weaknesses, and other pertinent information. I also send weekly emails to parents which provides any important information that they may need to know along with a list of missing assignments. This keeps the communication open, and parents are aware of what is going on in the classroom.  By starting to communicate from the beginning, we are familiar with each other. When it comes time for the IEP Meeting, we are not strangers. This can help ease any doubts the parent may have.


It is also important to have open communication with the student. Having a good rapport with the student helps in many ways. Once they feel comfortable, they are willing to work with me. Being able to talk to the student about their hops and dreams leads to the development of measurable annual goals.


Data collection is also needed. Before the goals can be written, a baseline needs to be identified.  The goals should be written to help build on what the student may be lacking in. The data should be listed in the Present Levels. When I progress monitor to collect the data on their goals, I make sure to explain why they are working on a certain skill.


Transition information, teacher input, and student/ parent input are all ways that parents and students can be apart of the development of their goals.

Subject: Anna Berzins- Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body:
There are a variety of strategies to engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals. Most importantly, an open line of communication is needed. Data collection, analyzing data, and working together with the family are also all crucial parts to including them in the development of the MAGs.

I communicate with students regularly and establish a rapport. Throughout the year I ask students to complete surveys, curriculum-based assessments, progress monitoring probes, etc. to collect data and have a baseline. Without good communication, it proves to be difficult to create goals together with the family. It is my job to ensure there is an open line of communication between the family and the school.

I make sure to review students' current academic and functional levels with students and their families. We discuss students' strengths and weaknesses, and if necessary, I encourage more data collection if there isn't enough.

After reviewing all the data, I review it with the student and family. I present the data in an organized fashion and encourage the student to steer the boat by asking guiding questions and leading the student to draw conclusions about their strengths and weaknesses. I ask the student what they'd like improve and together we create a list of some areas of needed improvement.

After those conversations have taken place, I then create goals based on student and family input, in language that can clearly be monitored on a bi-weekly or tri-weekly basis.

Families would have contributed through interviews and surveys when the student was assessed. The family and IEP team should always review annual goals so that everyone is on the same page and understands why the student has those specific goals. It is a priority that all parties be involved in the IEP process to understand what may impact the goals and use that information to assess and make important decisions regarding these goals to help the student achieve success. Subject: Rosemary Strausser - Feltonville Arts and Science M.S. LEA: Amy Davies

The student and their family should be engaged to identifying what they believe to be that child's greatest needs and how the school should proceed to monitor those goals. This can be done through surveys, assessments, phone calls and meetings. This way, everyone will be more prepared for the IEP meeting and understand how the school will be supporting that child and their goals. Also, the parents should be encouraged to keep up with the progress monitoring through reports. This will help guide them in understanding how their child is either progressing or not making progressing and how the team will tweak the goals.
