Subject: Shannon Sanders- Brandywine Heights HS- Dr. Reese
Body: I try and engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals by having on-going discussions/ contact and surveying students and parents. Progress monitoring can help and sending home draft of IEP prior to meeting can be helpful.  The data gathered for the meeting and discussions of data at the meeting can also help to shape the measur. annual goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Samantha Hagg- Northwest Tri-County IU5/North East School District
Body: A good place to start engaging students in the development of measurable annual goals is to have them engaged in the IEP process. By having them involved in tracking their present goals so that they understand what they are currently working on and why. Moving forward from there, having meaningful discussions at meetings where students hopes and dreams are linked to their individual needs.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lauren Stewart Interboro School District
Body: To help engage the students and families in the development of measurable goals I create an open line of communication in regards to their goals and any areas of strengths and needs that we can build from. Keeping an ongoing conversation via interviews, surveys, meetings, email, phone calls, etc. about the student's goals, why we are completing certain tasks to help achieve their goals, strategies we are using to help achieve their goals, progress, and continued areas of need with the student and their families allows for everyone to be involved in the process of making goals and also working towards the goals throughout the year.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Aubrey Cornes - Boyertown Area School District
Body: I engage youth and families in the development of their measurable annual goals by asking the student and their guardians for their input on the students  performance in their current class placement then compare it to the data we have to determine appropriate goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Heather Chero - Feltonville Arts and Sciences
Body: To engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals I have continuous open communication through out the year.  At the beginning of the year I ask the guardians what their preferred method of contact is. I also have families fill out surveys related to goals on what they find are their students strengths, weaknesses, and interests.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Janine Smith - Wyoming Area School District
Body: I engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals through interviews, participation in IEP Team Meetings, completion of the A.D.A.P.T. Parent Survey, and on-going discussions throughout the school year.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Christianne Cordovano// Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body: I engage families in the development of measurable annual goals through inviting them to attend the IEP meeting. During the meeting the draft goals are presented to the families. I ask the parent's input on the goals; there are times that I will create a goal based off a mutual concern presented by the family and teachers. I engage the student in the development of the MAG through meeting with the student prior to the annual meeting and going over the students' wants and needs. I often ask the student their opinions about the draft goals, and if the student has their own personal academic goal that they are reaching for.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kelly Trozzo - Seneca Highlands IU9
Body: We can ensure that students’ MPSGs are in alignment with their preferences, future plans, and dreams by using formal assessments as well as ongoing conversation. Ideally, the case manager should be someone that is familiar with the student and works with him/her regularly. This will also ensure the student's goals and expectations are realistic.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Ray Porreca- Feltonville School of Arts and Science/ LEA Amy Davies
Body: In order to make sure that attainable goals are assigned to the student there should be ongoing conversation throughout the school year between the case manager and the student, as well as with the student's family. Additionally, there should be time for teachers to share information about the student in question.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Joe Merhaut / Duquesne City SD
Body: Every year there should be a review of the students' strengths and interests. Ongoing communication with respect to the students and their progress and data is important to help students build knowledge of their progress. The parental involvement in the IEP meeting is also an important part of engaging the student.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Julie Lebovitz;Quaker Valley School District; Mike Lewis
Body: In creating or maintaining an appropriate measurable goal, I try to get the input of the student I am working with. If they are struggling to meet their goal(s) we can talk about those goale, why they are struggling to meet them and how to identify actions that can be taken to help them meet that goal. If they have met the goal, I engage them in a dialogue about whether they feel they still need that goal or whether it needs to be adjusted. It is important to discuss any changes with parents and teachers because their input can shed light on something I am not aware of!
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Melissa Zimmerman - LEA: Trina Knauff (AHCCS)
Body:
I engage students and their families in the development of measurable annual goals by inviting them to the IEP so we can discuss the IEP as a whole.  In addition, I write and send progress reports to update them on how the student is progressing - or not progressing - on his or her goals.  If the student is progressing - or reaches the goal - we discuss data, etc to come up with an updated goal.  If he or she is not progressing on their goal, the student and family should be included in the decision about accommodations or other aids that may need to be implemented. They should also be included in the decision about how to either help the student reach that goal or to adjust it or change it so that it's more achievable to the student.


How do you engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals?
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Christopher Thompson-Shenango Area School District-Dr. James Janacone
Body: The best way to engage the students and families is to have them attend the annual IEP meetings.  This will allow them to have input on the goals that are being created to help students progress on the path that is best for them.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Rebecca DelPrince - Bradford Area School District
Body:
We engage parents and students in the measurable annual goals through an invitation to the IEP meeting to discuss the document in its entirety.

We allow parents/student to address concerns, comments, strengths, weaknesses, preferences, and post-secondary information.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jennifer Morgan - Bradford Area School District
Body: The review of student performance data and results from formal assessments is a good place to start to engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Nicholas LaBella--Bradford Area School District
Body: Each year there should be a review of the students' strengths and interests. Ongoing communication with respect to the students and their progress and data is important to help students build knowledge of their progress. The involvement in the IEP meeting is also an important part of engaging the student.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: John Cress - ECSD - LEA Leslie Gleghorn
Body:
We will review the students strengths and needs to determine the best goal(s) for each student. At the IEP meeting, we will go over how the student performed on past goals and will update goals for the current year. We will also give progress reports each grading period to the parent and can notify if goals are regressing. 

We also pull students to test on goals and explain why they are being pulled to keep the students in the loop.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Ashley Hudson, Shenango Area School District (James Janacone, LEA)
Body: Ongoing communication is how I attempt to engage my students and their families in the development of MAGs.  As a related service provider, my students see me less frequently than their regular and/or special education teachers.  I attempt to discuss where they were and where we're attempting to go during each session.  This helps to align expectations and see the bigger picture.  For my younger students, I write a note to send home at the end of each session.  For my older students, I send messages using our district's communication system.  And as a new IEP approaches, interviews, surveys, and checklists help to open the lines of communication as the team looks to develop new MAGs.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Brian Keyser- Jamestown Area SD
Body: Sharing the evidence gathered on the student such as report cards, staff surveys, and observational information is important when engaging the student and their family.  However, it is just as important to seek evidence from the student and their parent/guardian and to take into consideration the variables outside of the school in writing MAGs.  The student and family should be heard when sharing their future goals for the student, whether it be in school or beyond high school.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Michelle Hall - ECASD (Leslie Gleghorn)
Body: I think the first most important thing is to have all the data ready. Since goals are developed from how the student is performing on achievement tests, assessments, in class, etc., it is imperative for everyone on the IEP team to begin with all the data that will be used to make decisions. Surveys are a great tool as well as open communication with parents and students about concerns, questions, and current progress before the meeting. I also feel it is invaluable for a parent to receive a draft ahead of time to have the time to take it all in so they can be ready for the meeting as well.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Anita McKeown, LEA Vanessa Nee
Body: I engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals through always maintaining open, honest lines of communication; getting to know the student & family better through conversation & interaction & I have found surveys to be invaluable. Family participation in the IEP is also important bc the IEP meeting is an appropriate platform to express concerns, and to discuss future hopes & dreams.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Paige Schmick, Achievement House Cyber Charter School.
Body: You should share the IEP with students and families so they are familiar with their measurable annual goals. Many students are not aware of their own goals. By making students aware of their goals, you are engaging them in the IEP process.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Noah Schweiger- NEB SD (Shannon Gorman LEA)
Body: As part of the IEP Team, the student and family should be contacted to determine what the most important goal is for them to master before graduation.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jamie Dunham - EPASD (LEA Colleen Livingston)
Body: In the past I have engaged students in their IEP goals by showing them their scores on their progress monitoring probes. I find that many students are not aware of their own goals. In addition, I've had sit down talks with students on how they can improve their scores - this has helped them to make strides in their learning.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Ashley Deurlein (Central Greene SD)
Body: Youth and families should be a part of the development of annual measurable goals through the use of verbal and written communication and collaborations which include but are not limited to: parent input forms and surveys, student surveys, and ongoing communication of progress monitoring and student achievment towards MAGs.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: William Friel (Interboro SD)
Body: I provide a parent/guardian input survey prior to our IEP meeting to address concerns and to make parent's feel apart of their child's future goals. As a part of the IEP team, we can then speak openly about any concerns and make the parents feel more at ease going forward. Measurable goals should be created and parents made aware of their student's progress. Without parental involvement, a student's ability to succeed may be more difficult.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Maggie Schaming - Quaker Valley SD (Mike Lewis)
Body: Students and families need to feel as though they are valued members of the IEP team. Creating a collaborative, trusting, and strong relationship with students and families is paramount to ensure the development of attainable and measurable annual goals. It’s a bonus to have informal, personal conversations with IEP team members, especially the student and families, to serve as a foundation before bringing the team together. This also ensures the team member that their input is valued as it is individually sought out multiple times during the process. By developing strong working relationships, team members will feel comfortable sharing ideas and/or concerns during the goal writing process.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jenna Maier, Shenango Area School District - Dr. James Janacone, LEA
Body: Youth and families should be involved in the planning process. Ongoing communication with the student and families is important.  Have the student and their family complete surveys, checklists and interviews so they feel like their thoughts and feelings are being considered when writing MAGs.  Follow up with the student and family members after the IEP meeting to address any lingering concerns.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sarah Hanna, Interboro HS LEA: Brain Lytz
Body: Sharing a student/family centered survey, sending home a draft IEP, and obtaining input/checking for understanding throughout the duration of the IEP meeting.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Antonietta Pollaro- Carrick HS
Body: Students and families are given a draft of the IEP and asked for their input towards the IEP.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Dana Luckenbill- EPASD (Colleen Livingston)
Body: I provide a parent/guardian input survey prior to the meeting.  I sit down with students prior to the meeting.  I send home draft documents to the family prior to the meeting.  I engage student and family in conversation at the meeting.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Ashley Jerome- EPASD- J. Miller-Reed
Body: Students and their families complete a survey to reflect on the strengths and needs. The needs/concerns are used, along with data and assessments, to create draft annual goals. At the meeting, the IEP draft is reviewed and a chunk of the meeting focuses on the goals. Once the team agrees on the focus of the goals, a goal is written/reviewed meeting the criteria required. The team agrees to this goal and it is instructed.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Valentyna Boucher- EPASD, East Pennsboro Area Middle School;
Body: During the annual IEP meeting, the case manager shares drafts of annual IEP goals to seek feedback from parents, students, and other IEP team members.  Prior to the IEP meeting, parents complete a parent input form where they address their student’s needs and strengths, both academic and functional.  The case manager shares the progress monitoring data that helps the IEP team approve students’ goals.  It is important to explain to parents why we focus on certain skills, and what is required of their students to meet the goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Mackenzie Bytof, EPASD- Miller Redd
Body: Making sure that the most important players in the student's future, the student and family, are attending the meeting. Hopefully, this occurs in-person. Ahead of the meeting, it is important to get both the input from the student (future planning) and the family's views. During the meeting, reviewing the current goal progress and the next steps for the student (AND EXPLAIN WHY that will help) is important to make sure everyone is on the same page for educational planning.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Megan Pine, LEA Janice Miller-Redd
Body: In order to engage families in the development of annual goals, the students family completes an input form online or verbally include their input at the IEP meeting. Also, we review the goal progress and discuss how we can update their goal to reflect their current present levels.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Todd Stuter, East Pennsboro, Janice Miller-Redd
Body: We provide various ways for families to participate in the IEP process.  Teams, Zoom or in-person are examples of way families can be involved. We emphasis to our students the importance of being involved in their own educational plan.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Janice Miller Redd
A, Wevodau
East Pennsboro SD
In order to engage families and students in development of goals, I use a Google Form to ask for input. I try to get the students to help pick their goals so they can have some degree of success fulfilling their IEP goals and make progress on them.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Alissa Fox-Edith Woods-Central Greene SD
Body: In order to engage families and students in development of goals, I like to send a Google Form to ask for input.  Also, I like to remind students in class what they need to work on and ask them if they feel it's helping or if they need additional help.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Trina Knauff - Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body: It’s important to review the student’s baseline data and progress for academic, functional, and transition needs, with both the students, parent(s)/guardian(s), and IEP team. This will help the team understand where they are presently achieving at for academic and functional need areas. The team should also review the student’s progress from the previous year to determine what their goal criteria would look like for the current IEP.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Billie Jean Tyler -Montgomery ASD - Kyle Brown
Body: After graduation from high school, the student and their families will be in charge of seeing the goals through to the end. They are a very important part of setting the goals, activities, and getting connected to resources in the community.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Annette Davis- DuBois Area School District
Body: You can engage youth and families in the development of both measurable annual goals and short term objectives in a variety of ways.  You could have a conversation before or during the IEP meeting about areas of strength and weakness and what the student and/or parents would like to see added or even removed as an annual goal.  You could also develop a checklist or google form to assist the entire team in the development of goals and objectives.  You can compare how each team member approached different subject areas in terms of strengths/weaknesses and goal development.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lauren Wetzel – Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body:
One of the most important factors of engaging youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals is creating a welcoming environment and becoming an ally.  The case manager should explain how the student needs are connected to their IEP goals.


I also find it helpful if students are aware of their progress (ie: sharing their progress monitoring data as it is collected), so that they are involved in their progress.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Julie Radakovich-Quaker Valley High School (LEA-Mike Lewis)
Body: To engage students and families in the development of measurable goals, it is important first and foremost to build a collaborative, working relationship. Once students and families understand that your role is to be an alliance, it allows for the school’s involvement to be supportive and authentic, assuring that the goals set are attainable and realistic. These relationships also assure that students and families are able to express their needs and concerns throughout this process, further supporting their comfort and participation in the IEP process.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Maureen Leidinger, Abington Heights Middle School; Elizabeth Shivock, LEA
Both students and families need to be involved in the development of measurable annual goals. The students need to be aware of how their needs are connected to the development of their goals. Teachers can engage students in the development of goals by meeting with students,  explaining their goals,  and explaining what students need to do to meet their goals. Furthermore, progress on goals should be shared with students. 

Families also need to be aware of students' goals, how progress is measured, and when students meet goals. This is accomplished in IEP meetings and through progress monitoring reports each quarter.  Families  can also  provide valuable information to the IEP team about needs they see at home that impact their child's school progress such as time management, study skills, self-advocacy,  etc. In this way, families are part of the goal development.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Rachel Whealdon, PPS
Body: Engaging students and families can be done by having the students and families complete a student and parent survey.  On these surveys you can ask what the concerns, needs and skills are.  This will help to make sure that the family and students wants and needs are documented.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Leigh-Ann Wilson (Philadelphia Electrical and Technology Charter HS)
Body: Engaging parents/families in the IEP process at the high school level isn't always easy.  The implementation of using Zoom video conferencing has certainly given us an edge on communicating with parents.  As the world has adjusted to this new way of life, it seems it has become increasingly easier to get families involved with the IEP process and goal development now that they can participate from the comfort of their own home.  Incorporating both parent and student input is crucial at the high school level.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Tony Banks- South Allegheny School District
Body: Ultimately the goal is to get students to take ownership of their future.  One must make the task seem as though it isn't work but fun to envision.  Parents can be notified of the progress but can also be given certain tasks to be involved with the student at home so that the effort is all encompassing.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Francis Rodia Interboro High School (IEA FORD)
Body: Student and family partnership in annual goals can occur through parent survey, student survey, and through interviews of each member of the IEP team. You can engage families and students in developing IEP goals with consistent and open communication with families.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Mags Progress Monitoring
Body:
Noel Skorvan South Allegheny HS/EC (Nicole Hoistek-LEA)

Having good relationships with students and their parents is a key component in working together to develop good annual goals.  If the students and parents are included and communicated with in regards to IEP development, they also become an active member in not only creating the goal but, working to make progress towards reaching the goal.  It becomes the entire teams equal responsibility to help the student make progress.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Vanessa Nee Wyoming Area
Body: We encourage our parents/guardians to be involved in the development of IEP goals.  We refer to the area of needs and encourage IEP team members to assist in the goals development. When a student has a need in the area of Math, Reading or Writing we use a progress monitoring tool to aid in our data collection. If there are behavior concerns, time management or organization we discuss the best way to monitor and draft a goal accordingly.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Deena Croyle, RIU6
Body: It is imperative that we involve the student and families in goal development. The purpose of the assessments should be explained to both the student and the families, as well as what information was gained from completing each assessment. Discussions between all members should be open and honest, and should involve interests, preferences, skills, and future goals. There should also be conversation about how the families can support these goals at home and in the community.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Bethany Wilson, IU6
Body: Students and their families should be involved in the entire process but giving input for goals and knowing what their goals are is critical.  Goals should align to a student's future aspirations and support and needs or deficits that may be a barrier to obtaining that aspiration.  Providing checklists and conducting either on paper or in person interviews to gather input are options. Allowing the student and their family to help prioritize goals is also important to help make the goals and the entire plan more meaningful.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Diana McMullen DuBois Area School District: Torie Sedor
Body: I first review the previous IEP to see if the goals written align with what the student will be learning and focusing on during the IEP calendar year.  I then include goal progress in the present education levels.  IF the goal is appropriately written, I will keep that goal just like it is.  If needs to be modified, then I modify it.  At the IEP meeting, I have a thorough discussion with parents and the student and explain where the child currently is, explain what the goal is measuring and tell why it is needed, and then ask both parents and students if they feel the IEP goal is acceptable and appropriate.  If it is then I keep it.  If it needs changed, then we work together to come up with a new goal and adjust the verbiage to make goals more appropriate.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Dr. Erin Grimm, AIU
Body: It is essential to involve students and families in the discussions regarding student needs based on interpreted academic and functional assessment data. These necessary discussions help to identify what can be supported with good instructional strategies and/or SDIs and what needs to be prioritized as a deficit that greatly impacts one's growth and progress academically and/or functionally within the school year. Additionally, the meaningful involvement of the student and family helps to discuss how skills can be further developed and practices at home and the community to create meaningful growth across all spectrums of the student's live (school, home and the community).
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Taylor Boonie - Juniata Valley: Lisa Coble
Body: Students and their families should always be engaged in the students IEP and their goals. IEP meetings should be held annually with the families. If families are unable to attend meetings, it is important to keep them updated and to gather any input they have. Check in regularly with the student to discuss any changes or progress being made. Send home surveys for parents and students to complete. Continually having open communication is going to be the best benfit.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Brian Clinger DuBois Area School District. LEA Torie Sedor
Body: The entire IEP Team with student and parent involvement is important for goal development.  A way to obtain student and parent information is through surveys and interviews prior to the IEP meeting.  The information collected will be beneficial for student achievement and writing the goals at the meeting.  A discussion and creation of the students goals with the IEP Team/Student/Parent being present at the meeting makes for a better outcome of goal mastery.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jennifer Gault- South Allegheny - Michael and Homistek, LEAs
Body:
All school personnel need to possess beliefs and mindsets to effectively engage families - relationships
Teachers and families have trusting relationships and meaningful two-way communication - trust
The special education teacher/case manager must engage families and the student in constructing goals together, monitoring progress, and supporting learning, as well as updating goals as necessary
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jocelyn Carr- Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body: We are able to engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals by providing to our students a variety of assessments such as teacher reports, parent interviews, student interview. These assessments are to be used to align with the student needs as listed from the reevaluation report as well as the present levels section of the IEP. With the data collected, we are to build and create the measurable annual goals.  The special education teacher is to progress monitor the goals and reflect the data through reports provided. This should be done at least quarterly or per parental request.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Ryan Brown - South Allegheny School District
Body: All stakeholders can increase their engagement towards achieving annuals goals by participating in surveys, attending annual meetings, and communicating regularly.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Nicole Talbert- Keystone Oaks School District
Body: By having a dialogue with the student and their families, reviewing their surveys and assessments we can help the student develop good annual goals that are in line with the post school goals we have developed. The two types of goals need to be harmonious and complementary with each other. Frequent communication is key.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Heather Hibner, EFSD
Body: Student and family engagement in annual goals can occur through parent survey, student survey, and through discourse/ interview.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Michael Routh, Elizabeth Forward
Body: Youth and families can be involved in the development of measurable annual goals by having frank discussions with district staff about the student's strengths and weaknesses.  Having a voice in the process from an early age can also facilitate this process.  Students need to feel valued and viewed as the centerpiece of the plan.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Alicia Hintze - LIU #18
To engage families and students in developing IEP goals teachers needs to have open communication with families. They can do this by having parent interviews, student interviews/surveys and frequent team collaboration/feedback throughout the duration of the IEP.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kristen Lovett: Abington Heights High School: Liz Shivock (LEA)
Body: Academic measurable annual goals are typically progress monitored bi-weekly at the high school itinerant level. Students review their goals, goal numbers, and what scores they need to attain on a continuing basis, so they understand what score they should be striving for. These score reports are shared with parents at least quarterly. They are also reviewed at all IEP meetings. Specially designed instruction typically align with their goal areas, and it is discussed how each SDI is used to help students meet success within the general education curriculum.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sara Reichold (Abington Heights - Elizabeth Shivock)
Body: The IEP team must collaborate with the student and their family to promote goal development. Assessments can be given to both the student and their family to provide numerous forms of relevant data. Understanding the purpose of each assessment and the role each party plays is important to encourage the creation sufficient measurable annual goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Joy Blasick, KidVentures Therapy, BASD
Body: Student and families should have ongoing input into the annual goals through informal interviews, inventories, checklists and assessments. School personnel can help students and families identify areas of need to develop measurable annual goals that tie in with their MPSGs.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Stacy Getz-Benton Area (Mary Rose Latorre)
Body: Engaging families in developing annual goals can include parent interviews, student interviews, surveys, and open discussion.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Justine Fernandes- City Charter High School
Body: Goals should include everyone on the IEP team, it is a process where the student and the family need to be aware and can contribute and make the teachers aware of what they believe the student needs to work on. The family can also work on these goals outside of school to help with the progress the student is having, this will help the student achieve the goal.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Myresa Sobocinski IU1 Itinerant CASD Jeanine Hudock
Body: Goal development should be discussed with the student prior to the IEP meeting. Involving them in the goal writing and showing them progress they have made can increase their involvement. Continuing with open communication with all IEP team members also increases engagement. Updating the student and IEP team members on the progress being made can increase engagement and the student can contribute and change goals if needed.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: MAGs and Progress Monitoring Coffee Talk
Body:
Mikayla Kemmerly 
(LIU OT - Northeastern School District) 
At the beginning of each school year and periodically throughout the school year, I review each students’ goal with them to ensure they understand what they are working towards. I will also periodically share their scores with them, as well as anytime they request to know their accuracies. In order to engage families, I will often call the families prior to IEPs that I will not be in attendance to review goals and gather their input. I like to make sure that the school team and parents are seeing similar concerns or needs. I encourage families to contact me whenever they have questions or concerns about goals or progress.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Measurable Annual Goals and Progress Monitoring
Body:
Megan Schoonmaker (Montgomery Area School District- Kyle Brown)
When monitoring current goals at the beginning of the school year I sit down with students to show them what kind of progress they have been making. When they complete a set of progress monitoring I show them the score they earned and we talk about how we should move forward. Doing this each time does not take very long and, in many cases, it helps to keep the student engaged and motivated. Parents are engaged more in the process during IEP meetings or if a student meets a current goal and there is a need for a revision. We talk about how the student did, what their current assessments look like and make a plan to move forward.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Natalie Rugg - QVSD: Mike Lewis (LEA)
Body: IEP teams need to work together and communicate throughout the entire process. During the assessment phase, students and parents can complete surveys and participate in interviews to obtain relevant information, which can translate into measurable annual goals. Also, if the student and parent understand the purpose of the goals, they can more readily contribute.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Leah Wells-Quaker Valley School District
Body: To engage students and families in the development of measurable annual goals a variety of activities occur. First, goal development is discussed with the student prior to the IEP meeting.  Student's play an active role in the development of goals that will best meet their needs.  Additionally, parent input is sought prior to the IEP meeting via a parent input form.  During the actual IEP meeting both students and parents are in attendance.  The team discusses potential goals and final goals are developed together.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Amy Rohrbach- Brandywine Heights SD
Body: In order to engage our students and their families in the process of developing goals, we need to be open and supportive of them from the start. As soon as a student is identified as needing special education services, we need to open the lines of communication and begin to include them on all of the data gathering and development of the IEP. It is important to have them all as involved as possible to create the supports needed using a team approach. We need them to be invested and feel like they are part of all the decisions made. Together, everyone can build a successful plan for the student's future.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kevin O'Toole, ECS Middle School
Body: We must communicate with parents and educate them on the same process we are using with the students--interest, career-matching, job skills identification, preparation and placement.  Once parents have a clear vision of this process, we can talk with them about what stage we see their child.  And then they and we can follow the student together through the process.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jessica Sharpe-South Middleton SD  LEA-Jessica White
Body: In order to engage youth and families alike in the development of measurable annual goals, we have to ask the right questions from the start and become very familiar with our students and their families. Understanding our students and their families helps us to gain more insight and perspective in the the student's needs, strengths, and preferences. When our students and families know we are interested then collaboration is created and there is positive and healthy conversations about measurable goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Tracy Costa-Interboro School District
Body: It is important to engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals early on.  Students and their families need to feel like they are supported and valued.  We need to ask important questions and get their input when developing goals. Open communication is critical in the process. Progress must be monitored frequently and communication must be ongoing for the students and their families.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kathleen Sanders- Abington Heights School District
Body: Engaging youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals through providing data to families and students. Student data is reviewed frequently with students, along with long-term goal. Data is gathered through progress monitoring, annual assessments, and benchmarks. Once data is reviewed and goal is established, data drives intervention utilized by the team. This information is shared with families quarterly. Teachers develop a positive rapport with families and consistent communication with families to assist in student success.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Deborah Riccobelli - Quaker Valley High School/School District
Body: Building strong relationships with students and families is integral to to the development of measurable annual goals.  Ensuring that young people and their families have an active role and voice in all processes of a student's education ensure that they feel comfortable and empowered during the goal writing process.  Frequent and ongoing communication is an essential part of helping students develop and attain their goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Amy Balbach-Quaker Valley School District
Body: I begin opening communication lines with students and families prior to the start of the school year.  Then, I look for ways to meet their needs throughout the year with regular, open communication.  A variety of styles are used to fit the preferences of different families (online surveys, phone calls, e-mail, etc.). Student and parent input is sought, and there are times when students initiate goals based on areas of need that they identify.  We then explore that area and add goals if necessary.  For other goals, we explore that data, provide rationale, and discuss applications for the goal when needed.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Brad Severson - Quaker Valley High School (Mike Lewis-LEA)
Body: It is vital to create an atmosphere where the family and student feel that they are a valued member of the team. I do not just speak at the family. I ask for input and explain my reasoning when we develop meaningful goals. An open dialogue occurs beyond the annual IEP. I give updates frequently and discuss short-term objectives with the family.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jessica Garavaglia - Quaker Valley High School (Mike Lewis-LEA)
Body: The key to engaging youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals is communication that is early and often. We all have strong relationships with our kids and their adults, so we commnicate with our families at last once a week. This communication and trust makes it easier to develop clear, appropriate, data-based goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Abigail Bator - Quaker Valley School District (High School)
Body: It is imperative that students and families remain engaged in the process of developing measurable annual goals.  Open communication is absolutely critical in this process.  Students and families must understand the steps of the process and what goes into the development of the goals; therefore, the learning support teachers must be well-versed and prepared to fully explain the process to them.  They must also continually monitor progress and update the students and families along the way, while also gathering feedback.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Heather Barto, Quaker Valley High School, Mike Lewis
Body: Families must be engaged in this process.  Communicating with families during times and modalities that they feeling comfortable with can help with continuous, ongoing, and open communication.  Making sure the student and family know that you are there with the student's best interests in mind will help them to trust your guidance.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Chad Smith- South Allegheny
Body: It is a continuous and inclusive process.  The student/family stays involved when communication is open and ongoing.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kimberly Dorus-Quaker Valley High School (Mike Lewis, LEA)
Body: Keeping open communication with the student and family will help to engage them in the creation of measurable annual goals.  It is important to take the time to explain and help families understand what measurable annual goals are.   We should use student and parent input to help drive the development of goals.  Checking on progress throughout the year and providing updates to the family will help to increase engagement of the student and family.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Melissa Groncki- Abington Heights (LEA: Elizabeth Shivock)
Body: Annual goals are created based on progress monitoring data, benchmarks, and annual assessments.  This information is communicated to the student and the family during the IEP meeting and by sharing quarterly goal progress. Students are engaged in the development of measurable annual goals because they are active participants during assessments.   Data is reviewed with students regularly. Interventions occur during class time.  Students are well aware of goal areas. Families are engaged in the development of measurable annual goals as participants of the IEP team.  They review data with the IEP team and provide input throughout the school year.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Robert Kelly - Interboro School District
Body: Keeping the student and their family engaged throughout the development of the IEP will keep them involved and available for providing input.  Working backwards from the desirable outcomes will help formulate goals in getting there.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kelly Quinn- Interboro School District- Ms. Cubito
Body: Teachers can engage the youth and families in developing the students measurable goal by communicating with each other. The parents/caregiving can also complete a parent survey. Teachers can ask the student what they want to work on to achieve their goal.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Matt Parrish- Quaker Valley SD
Body: Communicating with IEP stakeholders via formats and modes that are comfortable for them may increase willingness to provide honest feedback or data.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kim Boswell- Interboro School District
Body: Engaging families in development of annual measurable goals is as simple as engaging in a parent survey for feedback, and or asking the student what they would like to work on.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Danielle Schultz - Quaker Valley School District
Body: Families and caregivers should be part of the process in creating measurable annual goals that identify student needs.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kelly Smith-Interboro School District
Body: You can engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals by keeping an open communication with them. It is important to take the student and parent input and use them to drive the development of the transition goal. By providing updates, checking in on progress, and incorporate involvement of all IEP members, this will increase engagement of the student and the family.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kristy Johnson- Northwestern School District
Body: Engaging youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals is accomplished through many ways. At IEP meetings the team discuss strengths and concerns for the student.  Parent and student input is taken into account and as a team a goal formed. Keeping an open line of communication throughout the year helps to ensure everyone is comfortable and involved in the formation of IEP goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Danna Heh - Northwestern School District
Body: I am able to engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals by being in constant contact with the families. Things that are helpful include, student/parent surveys, student/parent interviews, phone conversations, and quarterly reports being sent home. By keeping those lines of communication open and constant updates on both ends, we are able to work together in forming those goals
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Brad Johnston - Northwestern School District
Body:
Pre IEP conference with parents 
Child interview and review of grades
Developing relationships and maintaining those relationships over the course of the students academic career
Parental input survey and allowing them to have an opportunity to share during the meeting. 
Student created materials to support career readiness and goals (electronic or paper pencil)
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Andrea Shilling - Northwestern School District
Body: It is important to engage everyone in a meaningful conversation of the baseline data to where we want the student to be. Families should fully understand and support the goals for the most student growth. This is important as we consider the future the student would like to have. Surveys, questionnaires and conversations will help communicate.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Annakaye Fenell-Northwestern School District (Kristen Rutkowski-LEA)
Body: Making sure that the student and families are involved in the development of measurable annual goals is extremely important, not only for the student, but for the teachers that have the student in their classes. By keeping the lines of communication open between the IEP team, the student, and the family, everyone involved with the student will have a better understanding of the interests and skills the student has and how they can form their goals. Also keeping the family and the student informed on the progress they are making in school is important for updating goals from year to year.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Julie Miller--NWSD--Kristen Rutkowski
Body:
In order to include the student and their parent, I have done the following:
*Sent surveys and/or check lists to be completed
*Interviewed the student and/or parents fo what interests they have and what they would like to do after high school.
*Looked over ERs and/or RRs as they are available
*Participated in discharge meetings with placement settings
*Participated in parent/teacher conferences
*Reviewed current grades and/or marking period goals
I try to keep up to date with what interests the student and what the family background is, in order to help guide the discussion of the IEP, and make recommendations as needed. Knowing what the student/parent wants to happen after high school, helps to guide how the MAG's are written.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Patrick Gaughan, Abington Heights High School
Body: Parental input is always taken into consideration during meetings and throughout the school year as to the needs that are required to be addressed for their child. When reviewing needs within the evaluation report/re-evaluation report, organizational skills, behavior, and transition needs, often times goals are created based on parent input that they feel a need exists in a certain area and that they feel their child would benefit from  measurable progress in that area.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sherri Emrich, Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body: I engage the student and families in the development of their measurable annual goals by allowing them to discuss what they feel are areas of need. Once they review areas of need, we compare those to assessments/data that would support if a goal is necessary. The student and family member can help prioritize the goals to focus on. Quarterly progress reports are sent to family members so they are aware how their student is progressing.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Paul John Holberg- Bedford Area School District
Body: The IEP team needs to keep measurable annual goals as up to date as possible.  Engaging the student and their families in this process is essential.  It can be as easy as sending a message, survey or email to the student and their families about how they feel the student is doing in their goal areas.  Having an open line of communication with the student and family will allow you to be able to have up to date goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jenna Bish - Northwestern School District
Body: Engaging families and youth in the development of measurable annual goals is important. Having meaningful conversations with the IEP team including the parent(s) and students along with utilizing interviews, surveys, and checklists are all ways to engage families in that process. Keeping students and families informed of student progress and maintaining communication between families, student, and IEP team is crucial.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sharon Mahoney, Northwestern School District
Body: Students & Families are a vital part of creating measurable annual goals. Their input is invaluable. Knowing student interests, activities, community involvement and abilities is imperative to the process. Working with students and their families, implementing surveys, engaging in interviews and working cooperatively are of prime importance.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lori Harmon - West Shore School District
Body: Having meaningful conversation with both students and parents when developing MAG's. It is important to know student strengths and needs, look at achievement of previous goals, and what skills the student will need to get to where they want to go.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: The families and students are included by requesting student and parent input for the RR and IEP. Interviews, surveys and checklists are all utilized. These goals can build into bigger goals, and adjusted or updated as necessary with increased or additional input from the student.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Rebecca Mausteller Line Mountain School District, Amy Dunn - LEA
Body: It is important to include the parents and students with the development of the measurable annual goals.   Reviewing and discussing the students areas of need and what they are having difficulty with in school should play a part in developing the goal(s) and making sure that they are measurable.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Danielle Mowery- Line Mountain- Amy Dunn LEA
Body: Engaging students and parents in the development of IEP goals is a part of the IEP meeting process.  Time should be spent on the goal section with all team members providing input and answering questions as they arise.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lori Ardeno – Jefferson Morgan
Body: It’s important to engage the student and families in writing the measurable annual goal, as the student will be the one working on this goal during the course of the year the IEP is in effect. Information we review to develop the measurable annual goals are: most recent re-evaluation report, current teacher / parent input, state and local assessments, CBA, and grades.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Maureen Donlevy Smith-West Shore School District
Body: To create meaningful goals, you must have an open dialogue with students and families as well as the team.  Looking at previously made goals is a good place to start and it is also helpful to look at their current performance.  I like to think of it as a roadmap.  Where are they, where should they be going?  Also, it is important to use the template and follow the format to make sure the goal is measurable.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Shari Brenizer- West Shore SD
Body: Engaging students and parents in the development of the MAGs is very important in the development of an IEP.  Having conversations with students and parents prior to IEP meetings and presenting the data from assessments and benchmarks is important.  Having students share their strengths and needs and asking parents what strengths and needs they see in their student is a way to have them involved in creating MAGs.   Using and sharing  the data from previous goals and Progress Monitoring of current goals with students and parents will help also with creating appropriate annual goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: April Smith (West Shore School District)
Body: To engage youth in developing measurable annuals goals, it is really important to make he / she is active in their goal progress.  Keeping students informed of how they are doing and maintaining an open dialogue with the student of their needs to help them meet goals is essential.  When encountering families, providing progress on goals, staying positively focused, but realistic increases engagement.  For both transition age youth and these families, keeping a clear transition based focus on goals also assists with key player engagement.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Laura Franks - Achievement House Cyber Charter School
Body: To engage students and families in the development of measurable and annual goals, I first review their progress monitoring data and current needs. I also gather updated information on their current grades, class participation, and teacher feedback. To engage students and families, it is important to ask for their feedback on how they think the student is progressing. This can be collected via a phone call, email, team meeting, or survey. Surveys can consist of a questionnaire asking parents about the questions or concerns they have. This can also give the parent the opportunity to communicate their thoughts on their child’s education.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Christine Braun - Millville Jr/Sr High School
Body:
LEA: Dee Davis
It is important to engage students and families in the development of measurable annual goals. I have a student interview where we discuss the results of progress monitoring and we talk about the goals and how they will be monitored and why they have those goals. I also send the goals home to the parents/guardians and then we discuss them at the IEP meeting. Whenever a student passes a goal, I discuss this with the student and parents and then we revise their goal accordingly.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Terri Rader - Central Fulton
Body: In order to engage youth and families in the development of goals, they need to be included in the IEP planning process.  It is important to ask the family about what they think the student's needs are.  Review the student's goals and progress from the previous year with the family. The more the family understands the more they will participate.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Lauren Baierl - Quaker Valley SD
Body: In order to engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals, it is important and necessary to ensure that youth and families understand what measurable annual goals are and are not. For example, explaining to families that annual goals are not related to monitoring grades is important. Also, goals should not be written if adequate data collection cannot be completed and reported in the quarterly reports.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jennifer Hoff - West Shore School District
Body: In order to engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals, it is important to focus on the progress monitoring data of current goals, baseline data of any new goals, the students’ strengths/needs and what skills will be needed to help the student achieve their post-school goals.  The goals thats necessary to meet their post-school goals should be indicated as services on the transition grid.  It is important to involve the student/family to show the correlation and importance between the two to ensure effective outcomes. Those services can repeated on each section of the grid as it relates to achieving their post-school goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Eric Healy - West Shore School District
Body: Students and families must be involved in the development of MAGs by discussions with the team prior to the meeting and during the meeting about their relative needs and strengths.  With the inclusion of the family, they are certain to have more engagement and become part of the the process.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Tina Williams -North East School District
Body:
LEA-Brianne Hodge

Collecting data from multiple sources is the first step in creating measurable Annual Goals.  This data comes from progress monitoring, teacher data from observations/ assignments/assessments/ interviews, parent interviews/surveys, and also student interviews and surveys.  After the IEP team has sorted the data and created an easily understandable form, it is then taken to the parents and students to discuss with them the child’s greatest needs, the goals and how they will be monitored.  Informing them of the data collected allows them to ask questions, provide more information and be part of the collaboration during the goal making process.  This helps the student understand their baseline and the goals they have helped set.
Author: Anonymous

Body:
Bill Barton-DuBois ASD
I engage with families by calling them when developing the MAG's. I inform them that during the meeting if we need to change/amend any goals we can do that at the meeting. I will ask them to email me information so that I may add it to the IEP.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Mike Orsi, Keystone Oaks High School, LEA-Mike Linnert
Body: It's important to engage students and families in the development of measurable and annual goals by utilizing communication between student, teachers, case manager, and family. It is important to include everyone for to provide valuable input.  Goals are driven by this communication.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Heather Hull, West Shore School District
Body: I engage students and families by starting with their local and state assessment data.  In addition, I make sure to include a summary of each data set that clearly emphasizes the student's areas of need and strength.  Since these are what help us determine the measurable annual goals, it is important to help families and students focus on these as well.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Janel Reinfried, West Shore School District
Body: I engage students and families in the development of measurable annual goals by reviewing the data from the student's progress and their current needs.  I feel this is a great start to let them know where the student has started, why we are working on a current goal and then what the goal will help them achieve.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Diann Vera - Millville Jr/Sr High School
Body: In order to develop attainable, valid MAGs, teachers need to gather and analyze important data from progress monitoring, discussion with students, teachers, and parents.  The student needs to understand the purpose of progress monitoring so he/she can give the best effort.  Without a clear understanding of a student's baseline ability, good goals cannot be established.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Heather Kozich-Central Greene-Edith Woods
Body: I believe that baseline data is key in the writing of measurable annual goals. Meaningful communication between school and home is important when trying to involve the family. All concerns listed in parental input should be listed and address with care and concern.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Emma Klesen-Central Greene School District- Edith Woods
Body: Engagement of the student and their families is extremely important. A teacher can call the parents of the student and physically talk with them over the phone or teachers can send out a questionnaire/survey and have the parents fill it out. There can be a space left on the questionnaire/survey asking if the parents have any questions or concerns so that anything specific can be addressed and this can help the parent feel that they do have a say in their child's education.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kelly Myers - Millville Area School District
Body:
LEA- Dee Davis
You can engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals by ongoing communication, checklist, interviews, and surveys . Active participation in the IEP planning processes is key to creating measurable annual goals that are attainable. It is also imperative to invite youth and families to IEP meeting to have discussions about student progress, review progress monitoring data, and gain parental input about student strengths and weaknesses.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Brittany Fisher - Millville Jr/Sr High School - Dee Davis as LEA
Body: There are many ways to engage youth and families in the development of MAGs. Through the development of IEP and even during the duration of the IEP, students and parents need to be actively involved in all IEP decisions. This requires the use of ongoing, open communication. Input needs to be collected by all parties involved in the process whether it's in written form from surveys or verbal input provided. This input should be data driven based on progress monitoring data, state and local assessments, etc. The data needs to be analyzed to identify strengths and weaknesses to be able to develop clear MAGs. Once the goals are created and are being monitored, input on the progress or lack there of need to be provided to the student and parents on a quarterly basis to determine if revisions need to be completed.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Rose Chiprich-Central Greene-Edith Woods
Body: It's important to have input from all members.  Getting the student involved prior to the IEP meeting, will provide you with a clear picture of what goals the student wants to work towards. Providing the parent with a questionnaire/survey, will also allow the parents to feel that they are part of their child's IEP and have some input.  Communication is a key to engaging the families.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Michelle Murray-Intermediate Unit One (assigned to Jefferson-Morgan School District)
Body: In an effort to engage youth and families in the development of MAG we involve the family and student in discussions throughout the IEP process. These discussions include a review of all assessment data obtained, current student progress, student post-secondary vision. Teacher input, parent input, as well as student input are all reviewed with the team.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jordan Cernaloger - Central Greene School District
Body: Students and families can be involved in the development of measurable annual goals by being involved in the discussion of the student's strengths and weaknesses. If they can help identify areas in which the student needs to improve, they will be more likely to engage in the progress monitoring process. If they feel that the students goals are meaningful they are more likely to be involved in the development. Goals can be shown to be meaningful by involving data collection and having measurable outcomes. Students and families will "buy in" so to speak if they can be shown that students are making positive progress.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jeff Coss-Central Greene-Edith Woods
Body: Parents need to be involved in the entire IEP process including the goals.  But for this to happen the parent's must want to be included.  We call/email home, invite them to open house and IEP meeting but all too often we get no parental participation.  Some of the ownership must be taken by the parent's the school district can only do so much.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Brion Stone (Mountain View) (LEA: Erica Loftus)
Body: Prior to the IEP meeting our team takes information from assessments, teacher recommendations, and other sources and decides on what the most important thing for that specific student to improve during the duration of the new IEP. At the meeting once the team presents the goals to the parent/guardian we ask them if they feel this is an appropriate goal. From there we either keep the pre-made goal or we come up with a new goal.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kelsey Tate - Central Greene School District - Edith Woods
Body: We can engage families and students in the measurable goals we create for them by making sure that the family understands what the goal is and that they also understand how it will be measured. Often times, students become frustrated with progress monitoring because they do not understand the goals they are trying to meet in the first place. By letting them know what they are and the importance of having them, they will then be more likely to have no issue with us measuring said goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sarah Wright - West Jefferson Hills School District
Body: We engage students and families in the development of measurable and annual goals by continuous communication of the goals between the student, teachers, case manager, and family. It is important to include everyone for to provide valuable input.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Rebecca Karluk-Central Greene-LEA Edith Woods
Body: It's important to include input from students and parents/guardians throughout the IEP process and the development of goals.  Start with their baseline skills and make sure that they can be accurately monitored.  Goals should contain: measurable, accountable data that can be monitored.  They need to be written in general, not broad, terms.  Be specific as to the time frame for goal monitoring.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Danielle Fritz - Millville Area School District
Body:
LEA - Dee Davis

Students and families are activiely involved throughout the IEP writing process. Goals should be guided by previous and current data assessments completed by the students. Parents are also given the opportunity to provide input on goals. Goals are centered around specific student needs. These needs are gathered through meaningful academic assessments and observations. Progress monitoring should be completed and reviewed as a team with the student and family.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Kandyss Sutphen - Millville Area School District, LEA Dee Davis
Body: In order to engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals you must write them in terms that are not so broad that they cannot be progress monitored.  They must be objective, not subjective and based specifically on student need.  The timeframe is also important.  Engage the student and family in making all of those decisions by inviting the student and family to the IEP meeting, encouraging their input, and making them feel their input is valuable.  Make a plan together and keep lines of communication open.  That way everyone can feel they were a part of the goal setting, overall plan, and eventually, the successful outcome.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Sheri Ransom - Mountain View School District
Body: Important pieces of developing the Measurable Annual Goals is through data collected in the classroom, a variety of assessments, CBAs, teacher input, parent input, student input, student needs and also looking at the students post secondary goals so that everything aligns and supports these goals.  The goals should have realistic expectations and should be adjusted if the TEAM determines a need to revisit them.  Communication is important with all team members as we remember that the IEP is a living document and can be revisited and revised.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: VailIU1Ininerant-Carmichaels
Body: Students and families should be incorprated in the writing of MAG by using the students needs that have been determined based on student/parent/teacher interviews and assessments. The students and families should then use these needs to come up with 3-5 needs that they feel are more important to prioritize and create goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Carrie Witherite- DuBois Area School District
Body: It is very important to involve youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals. Have discussions with the student and parents to find out what they feel are important goals. Have them fill out interviews and surveys. Keep the student and parents updated on progress toward the goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Melissa Franks, Susquehanna Community, Joni Deakin, LEA
Body: Classroom data, various assessments, parent input, teacher input, CBAs, etc. are all important pieces to developing measurable annual goals.  Involve the students and parents from Day 1 and keep them updated as changes occur.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Megan Boozer, Jamestown Area School District, Gary Kinnear
Body: Measurable annual goals are all based on the students needs and current levels. During the IEP process it is important to involve families and youth in the creation of the Annual goals. By inviting families and youth to the IEP meeting you are opening the door for their input with the creation of  annual goals.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Karen Beck-LEA is Lisa Coble-Juniata Valley School District
Body: You can engage the student and the family in the development of measurable annual goals by beginning with a baseline of the data.  The students/families are presented with progress reports and then that information can be discussed and adjusted to make a better measurable annual goal.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Dan Waite Juniata Valley School District Lisa Coble LEA
Body: The goals must be based on the students ability levels and the parents and student need to be involved by looking at the needs of the students, which have been identified in the IEP.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Cathy Grieb-JVSD-LEA Lisa Coble
Body: Involve the students and parents by inviting them to IEP.  Review assessments/data and surveys and then as a team develop goal.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Paige Bodenschatz-WSSD
Body: Getting families involved requires asking them and involving them in the planning of the students future and what they would like to see for their son or daughter.  It also helps, to keep them informed of what their son or daughter want to do and what their data currently looks like in classes.  It helps to provide assessments and interviews from the student for parents to understand.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Shelly Quimby - Shenango Area School District - LEA:  James Janacone
Body: Youth and families can be engaged in the development of annual goals by having them involved in the planning process.  Be sure to have ongoing communication with the student and families.  Have the student and their family complete surveys, checklists and interviews so they feel like their thoughts and feelings are being considered.  It’s also important to follow up with the student and family members after the IEP meeting to address any lingering concerns.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Emily Leininger - WJHSD
Body: Families should be involved in the development of measurable annual goals. As a team, we look at the students’ strengths and needs. Classroom data, assessment scores, teacher input, and parents input and concerns should all be addressed and considered.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Pete Murphy-West Jefferson Hills School District
Body: As the building LEA, IEP goals need to be written with language that make it clear what skill is being developed, what the target is, and how often the skill will be evaluated.  Parents should be a part of developing the annual goals based on what skills they feel their children are most deficient at.  Often, parents look to the school as being the expert in writing the goal(s) that their children will hope to achieve during the upcoming cycle.  As the LEA we must assure that we are writing goals that we can measure and are specific to the individuals skill deficit(s).
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Megan Morgan - WJHSD, LEA- Jade Fiore
Body: In order to engage you and families in the development of their goals, we as a team look at their pattern of strengths and weaknesses and prioritize what skills are most important to address in the present IEP.  We look at all available data to include present levels of performance, current formal and informal assessment data as well as post-secondary interests.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jonathan Doyle - WJHSD
Body: You can engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals by having them involved in the process from start to finish. Also by allowing them to have input on what areas of improvement or level of achievement. continues data and communication also helps.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Jade Fiore- WJHSD West jefferson hills sd
Body: Goals should be written with the input of the caseload manager and staff who work with the student. The goals should focus on the individual needs of the studentan. Having constant communication with the student and parents is key, as they will provide valuable input.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Will Boger - WJHSD
Body: When engaging students and families in developing goals, my process includes classroom data, student conversations and parent input.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Chris Cieply - WJHSD
Body: In order to engage youth and families in the development of their goals, I first do my due diligence on the child by analyzing and observing current classroom performance and determine areas of need using classroom based assessments. From there, I ask for and use parent input to help to determine where to take their current goals and adjust accordingly. After those goals are developed, follow up communication with the student and parent is key and the goals can be modified if the student/family and IEP team are not on the same page afterwards.
Author: Anonymous

Subject: Ashley Paradise - WJHSD
Body: Reviewing all current data, as well as, transition plans help the IEP team, including the student and his/her family, to remain engaged in the process of developing annual goals. Reviewing parent and student input, as well as, any concerns that they have can also help to shape the process of writing annual goals. If there is a goal that a family feels is not important or could be tweaked, the team can discuss and adjust the goal as needed.

Subject: Bridget Stright- WJHSD

Subject: Michael Boston - Redbank Valley School District - LEA Mr. Josh Temchulla
Body: Most often, I engage students in their measurable annual goals by reviewing the progress monitoring assessment results with them, sharing what skills we need to target (and why), as well as where we are going.  Then, we identify how much progress we believe we can achieve within the next IEP year.  This can mean that the IEP goal might have an average accuracy percentage of 80% or 90%.  It might be 60% because that is the student's pace.  It is true, in the midst of this, to challenge students to increase the rate of their progress where appropriate.  Then, during session times, providing feedback about their progress (using charts, graphs, or progression from session to session) assists students to evaluate their own progress and to already anticipate what their progress reports will state.  Families are then included during progress reporting time.  I also discuss re-evaluation and evaluation data over the phone with parents so that they understand what each area of need is - in parent-friendly language.  In addition, we discuss what skills are needed to develop (and why we are targeting them).  Parents have the choice of whether or not to offer a change of the IEP goal.  If a change is needed, this is also brought before the student to re-evaluate as well.  Further collaboration between all parties is sought if needed.

Communicating with the student and parents about the data, rather than simply sending home a progress report, and taking the time to discuss why scores may have dropped, or coming up with revised goals where needed/writing new goals if students achieved mastery, is also important.

Subject: David Blom- East Pennsboro High School- LEA- Colleen Livingston
Body: Goals should focus on the skill deficit and what the student would like to focus on. The student should be an active participant in the writing of the goal or revision of goal. Not all students are ready to self-monitor but students should be part of the data collection and monitoring of goal when they are able to be. Parents should have input prior to the IEP meeting but also be given an opportunity at the IEP meeting to discuss and be part of revising goals if necessary.

Subject: Rachel Henney SMSD
Body: Including teachers, students and families in the transition/IEP process, by interviewing and completing various assessments, will assist with development of accurate and measurable annual goals.

Subject: Caroline Zugell- South Middleton School District
Body: In order to engage students and families to develop measurable goals, it is important to have open communication with the student and the family.  There should be assessments to gather information and establish strengths and needs. The entire team must work together to determine what is best for student.

Subject: Steve Doland-South Middleton School District
Body: Discussing student strengths and needs with the student and the rest of the IEP team is the best way to engage families with the development of IEP goals. The team should understand the purpose of the annual goals and that the goals are a true way to measure growth and do not exist in a vacuum.

Subject: Jennifer Harclerode-Bedford Area School District
Body: To engage students and families in developing measurable annual goals an open dialog must be established. Being in constant communication with families help to build a foundation of an open partnership in the development of the whole IEP not just the MAGs.  Regularly assessing and reviewing results with students help to create more accurate and precise goals that will help show the student where they are growing and what they need to continue to do to meet the annual goal.

Subject: David Robinson - South Middleton School District
Body: Engaging students and families in the development of annual goals comes down to maintaining regular communication between home and school, continuously assessing students, and continuously analyzing the results of assessments with the help of IEP team members (including the student and family).
