Subject: Mandi Abernathy- South Middleton SD
Body: Youth and families can be engaged in the development of measurable annual goals by whole team discussion of present levels, transitional goals, and current goal progress and then creating student goals as an IEP team based on data and all other factors. This discussion would also include the student/parent/and teacher input provided. Students should be actively involved in monitoring and tracking their progress and families should receive progress updates/feedback as stated in the IEP and anytime in between as concerns arise or a goal needs to be adjusted.

Subject: Carrie Miller - South Middleton School District
Body: Including the student and family in the IEP meeting and when goals are created is the best way to engage them in the development of measurable annual goals. Explaining assessments and how the student performed is essential to their engagement. Reviewing the “why” is often very important. Keeping recommendations fluid and open to edit or changes can be a big way to engage the family and keep a students’ interest. Progress is best made with the student on board vs being asked to do something they see no value in.

Subject: Rebecca Russell - Central Greene SD
Body: Including the student and parents in the writing of IEP goals for transition is one way to engage the entire family. Usually, our IEPs are written in advance, but they are sent home ahead of time to allow for parents to review them. This would allow them the opportunity to offer input, and we could modify the goals before the IEP is implemented, ig needed. Students can be involved even more, if time allows, by meeting with the case manager during school and discussing their wishes for the future. You could write the goals together and then discuss with the parents at the IEP meeting.

LEA- Jesse White

Discussions can be held via; email, telephone, or formal meeting.  I update goal progress quarterly with parents via a formal letter, but will email if something concerning or overly positive comes to light.

Body:
How do you engage youth and families in the development of measurable annual goals?

In developing measurable annual goals, students and families are engaged in the process in several ways.
1. Student assessment data - share the results of formal, informal, classroom based measures, teacher report and observations.
2. Student interviews - discuss with student what accommodations or supplementary aids/services is currently working, can be taken or should be added.
3.Parent interviews:  discuss their observations, share the accommodations, supplementary aids and services - what is working, should be added or taken out based on student need.
Taking all of that into consideration along with other members of the IEP team, using professional judgements, student strengths, weaknesses and needs, create goals that will enable progress.  Throughout the year, with progress report, and other intermittent communication modalities, updating parent and student of progress and making adjustments as appropriate to encourage continued student growth and progress.
Janice~EPASD

Body: Engaging youth and families in developing MAGs requires analyzing multiple sources of information including evaluations, classroom based assessments, student observations and input from parents. It involves looking at where a student wants to be after high school, and basing goals on current logical steps necessary to help meet those goals in the future. ~Kat Llewellyn
Author: Anonymous

Body: Students and their families are an essential part of the IEP process. Discussions centered around present levels, strengths, and weaknesses should occur frequently in order for students to buy into and participate in the monitoring of their IEP goals. Students and families need to be part of the discussion in order for appropriate goals to be developed and agreed upon by the IEP team as a whole. In order for students to try their best for progress monitoring they need to know what is being monitored, by who, when, and how frequently. -Kirsten Kalista
Author: Anonymous

Body: Students and families should consistently be part of the IEP process. That means reviewing data regularly, especially with the student as we push for them to become more independent. The data becomes more meaningful for the students when they understand what is happening and why. They are also more likely to push to do their best when they understand the purpose. Conferencing often with students regarding their progress is important. It is also helpful to ask for their input in creating the goals. They should be able to identify what they feel are their areas of need, so building on that information together can be helpful in creating the MAGs. If we encourage and assist students and families throughout the entire IEP process, they will feel welcomed to help build the goals alongside the rest of the IEP team. - Nicole Clemens

Body: To engage youth and families in developing MAGs you could share the results of benchmark testing, pointing out both areas that the students excels at in addition to the areas the student is struggling with. Explain the relevance of the skill in the student's academic and daily life. (ex: Time skills will help a student for the rest of their life) - Vicki Kulp

I encourage LEAs to engage youth and their families in the development of Measurable Annual Goals by stressing the importance of assessment and helping them understand that the student should be an integral part of the IEP process.  The student and family should be aware of the goals they are working on, and the progress they are making toward these goals.  When it comes time for the Annual review of the IEP, assessment data should be shared with the student and their family so they can be a part of what will happen next: should we keep the current goal and increase criteria?  Should we end the goal because it was met?  Do we have other new needs based on assessment that should be given priority for this next IEP term?  All of this information can help ensure students and their family are engaged.
